FREE MEALS TO ALL STUDENTS: Beginning Monday, September 14, Pike Road Schools' Child Nutrition Program (CNP) will provide all school meals (breakfast and lunch) to students free of charge.
Because of the current health pandemic, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) passed a waiver that funds free meals for students through December 31, 2020. This unprecedented move ensures that students have access to nutritious food.
All student account balances will remain for use throughout the school year. Please note there will still be a charge for items not covered under the USDA waiver (additional beverages, extra entrée, and specialty items such as Chick-fil-a sandwiches).
Free meals will be served simultaneously with our regular dining program. Virtual and blended learners that want to pick up meals daily will receive instructions on pick up times and entry points directly from your school by the end of this week. There is no application or paperwork required.

Pike Road Schools would like to welcome our new head softball coach, Patricia Ball.

Coach Ball holds a career record of 841-450-2. She is 4th in all times wins amongst AHSAA softball coaches.
Ball’s softball achievements Include:
• 2011 6A state title
• 2010 6A runner up
• 3rd place finishes 2007 & 2012
• 9 Elite 8 Appearances
• 14 Regional Appearances
• 11 Area Titles
She was voted Alabama Sportswriters Association 6A Coach of the Year in 2010 and 2011.
Coach Ball comes to Pike Road Schools from Dothan High School, where she was the head softball coach for 24 years, athletic director for three years, physical education teacher for ten years, and a science teacher for 16 years.

PRS Welcomes Gregory Foster as principal of PRHS-
Pike Road Schools is pleased to announce that Gregory Foster has been named the Pike Road High School principal. Mr. Foster comes to PRHS from Roanoke City Schools with 17 years of administrative experience.

Mr. Foster served the past ten years as the principal at Handley High School. Under his leadership, Handley High School was awarded as one of the Best High Schools by US News and World Report 2012-2015, a CLAS Banner High School in 2012, 2014 BEEP Award, and 2014 FOC.

Mr. Foster brings years of educational expertise and experience to PRS.
His professional experience includes athletic director at Handley High School, principal of Handley Middle School, assistant principal of Handley Middle School, and high school teacher.

Mr. Foster is an outstanding leader, and we couldn't be more excited to have him as part of our district's leadership.

CONSTRUCTION UPDATE: Pike Road Schools is proud of the progress at our Historic campus as it pertains to the addition of classroom space.
Here are some of the highlights on the additional space at the Historic campus:
•12,252 square feet of additional classroom space.

•10 of the classrooms are roughly 820 square feet each.

•Two additional classroom are smaller and may be used for special needs children and study areas.

•The addition includes a storm shelter that consist of 3,400 square feet of space that covers the main corridor, one large classroom, and the restrooms.

•The storm shelter has storm rated doors and a power back up system that will maintain power to the shelter area for up to 2 plus hours.

•The construction incorporates 12" poured concrete and steel reinforced rebar walls with 5.5" of concrete for the ceiling lid reinforcement and steel bar joist.

•The project is scheduled to be complete prior to the start of the 2020/2021 school year. Once complete this campus will serve all 4th-6th graders attending Pike Road Schools.

February is Black History Month-
At Pike Road High School located at the Georgia Washington Campus we walk the halls of this history daily. We are proud to honor and learn about our heritage.

Georgia Washington was born a slave in Virginia; she was sold along with her mother, away from her father. After emancipation she graduated from Hampton University (1882), an HBCU in Virginia where she taught for a while before moving to Mount Meigs, Alabama, and starting a small school there called the People's Village School. In February 1894, the residents bought a plot of land and built an 18-foot-by-36-foot schoolhouse. When Georgia Washington died in 1952, the school was named in her memory. The first timepiece for the Mt. Meigs community, is a brass bell, which is housed in the very hallways we walk every day. The bell is a reminder of the sacrifices and accomplishments of one brave woman for the purpose of education.
Let's Remember, Educate and Celebrate Black History Month.
